video.title: NASA's Original Post-Apollo Plans Were INSANE | Answers With Joe

content.summary:
Right after Apollo, the United States seriously considered an integrated roadmap that would build a reusable Space Transportation System, a permanent space station and lunar base, and send astronauts to Mars by the early to mid-1980s. The key idea was simple and compelling: keep momentum by turning Apollo’s one-off triumph into a permanent, scalable presence in space, culminating in Mars as the next clear destination. It didn’t happen—not because physics made it impossible, but because budgets, politics, and priorities shifted.

First, the headline goal was explicit: crewed exploration of the planets, with Mars as the first big step. The plan treated Mars not as a stunt, but as the organizing objective that would guide every decision. That focus would drive technology choices in life support, propulsion, on‑orbit assembly, and surface operations, so that each investment fed into a long-term capability rather than a dead end.

Moving on to the stepping stones, the architecture started in low Earth orbit. A fully reusable shuttle would ferry people and cargo up and down routinely, ideally by the mid-1970s. That shuttle was paired with a permanent space station—initially a dozen people, expandable to dozens—serving as an orbital worksite for assembly, testing, and long-duration crew experience. Add a “space tug” for moving payloads between orbits and cislunar space, and you get a logistics chain that makes everything else cheaper and more repeatable.

When it came to going beyond Earth orbit, the plan leaned on heavy lift and advanced propulsion. Saturn V derivatives, or a new Nova-class booster, would push large modules to orbit for assembly. For deep space, nuclear thermal propulsion—specifically the NERVA program, which had already achieved specific impulse around 850 to 900 seconds in ground tests—would halve propellant needs compared to chemical rockets. The same playbook extended to the Moon: establish an orbital platform and then a lunar surface base in the late 1970s, both to conduct science and to harden systems for Mars.

As for timelines and scale, the aggressive options aimed for a first Mars mission as early as the 1981 launch window, with more conservative paths landing in the mid‑1980s. Either way, the mission profile centered on a conjunction-class journey: assemble the ship in Earth orbit using multiple heavy launches, transit to Mars, stay roughly 500 days on the surface to wait for favorable alignment, then return. Typical studies envisioned on the order of six to eight Saturn V-class launches per mission and crews of four to six.

However, there was an important trade-off: this only worked if the elements arrived together. The shuttle made sense if it fed a station and a tug, which together justified continuous heavy-lift and nuclear propulsion. Break that chain, and the economics and purpose of any single piece got weaker.

So why didn’t it happen? The short answer is money and politics. By 1968, all Saturn V boosters for Apollo had already been built, and the national “race” was effectively over. NASA’s budget, which peaked around 4.4 percent of federal spending in 1966, fell below 1 percent in the early 1970s. The Vietnam War, inflation, and domestic priorities crowded out big new commitments. The White House wanted a cheaper path, the Office of Management and Budget was skeptical of Mars timelines, and Congress had little appetite for another decade-long moonshot.

Faced with cuts, NASA tried to save the part most likely to survive: the shuttle. To win approval, it promised airline-like operations—up to 50 flights per year at $10–20 million per launch in 1970s dollars—and accepted design compromises to reduce development cost, including solid rocket boosters and a large external tank, as well as a delta wing with high cross-range to satisfy the Air Force. Without the station, tug, or heavy-lift production line, the shuttle became a destination in itself. Reality fell far short: typical flight rates were five to nine per year, and per‑launch costs ballooned into the hundreds of millions, ultimately over a billion dollars when fully burdened. Meanwhile, NERVA, despite excellent test results, was canceled in 1973, and Apollo missions 18 through 20 were scrapped. What survived were Skylab in 1973, Apollo‑Soyuz in 1975, and then decades of low Earth orbit operations.

It’s worth noting what did move forward with that “balanced approach” they argued for. Robotic exploration blossomed: Viking 1 and 2 landed on Mars in 1976, and Voyager 1 and 2 launched in 1977 for the grand tour of the outer planets. But for human spaceflight, the integrated, stepwise path to Mars evaporated when its pieces were funded piecemeal. The result was a long detour before rebuilding an integrated architecture with the International Space Station, today’s Artemis lunar plans, and new heavy-lift and fully reusable vehicles.

In the end, the post‑Apollo master plan was ambitious but internally consistent. It didn’t fail on technical grounds; it failed on sustained commitment. The bottom line? If you want Mars, you fund the whole chain—reusable transport, permanent infrastructure, and advanced propulsion—and you keep that funding steady across election cycles. The practical takeaway today is the same as it was in 1969: set a clear, singular destination, build the capabilities that compound toward it, and resist one‑off “flags and footprints.” Momentum is everything, and once you stop, you don’t just pause—you lose hard‑won capacity that can take decades to rebuild.
